data.title: Alan Gershwin

data.text:
In 1959 Confidential, an American magazine, published a story headlined: “I am George Gershwin’s illegitimate son”. A montage of the juxtaposed profiles of Gershwin and the writer of the piece was captioned: “Which one is the son?” While the two were hardly identical, the similarity was striking, especially the full-lipped mouth.

The “son” was Alan Gershwin, whose mother, he said, had had an affair with George, who died in 1937. Once, Alan said, during the Second World War, while he was stationed in Charleston, South Carolina, where George Gershwin had written Porgy and Bess, an elderly black man told him: “Mr Gershwin, we always knew you’d come back!”

He also claimed that when George’s mother, Rose, met Alan before she died, she was overcome with
